combined_text: The 1/8" jack has stopped making a good connection with my iPad's female jack so the headphones are virtually worthless now. Great price to value ratio. These are my go-to cheap over the ear headphones.  For those of us who cannot use your buds, this is a solid choice. This is the best earphone for audio books. Been ordering it for years. nice headphones worth buying Great sound, very comfortable, durable cord.  Unlike most headphones I've dealt with recently, this cord actually holds up really well! The one downside is that the size adjustment portion on the band is pretty weak. Mine broke, so I'm buying a new pair. Honestly, great deal for the price. I still use them with the size adjuster bit broken. I've previously paid a lot more for headphones that were no better than these.  I use them on my computer and my MP3 player while in my home only because I hate when sound leaks from my headphones in public and people can hear what I'm listening to, however, for around the house these headphones are great. These handy little headphones are a fine buy at the price.  The sound quality is good, and they are comfortable on my ears.  I wear glasses, and some headphones don't work well over the frames. This set fits comfortably.  I use them every day, mostly to listen to the radio and they are holding up well.  And, my family doesn't have to listen to my choice in music and news...........

7. The sound is excellent, especially given the price. It is much, much better than the one I was using before. Heavy bass ROX!!!
8. Volume control slider on the cord puts volume adjustment at your fingertips
9. Aesthetically pleasing
10. Clearly marked for left and right ears

Cons:

1. Four foot cord is rather limiting
2. This model doesn't include a microphone for those who like to chat on-line
3. I'm spending more time listening to music when I should be doing something else

Overall: Great value for the price

Rated: 4.5 stars

Amanda Richards, June 10, 2008 I ordered these because of the reviews they'd received regarding the sizing and the sound. All of the good reviews are right on. These are NOT $300 headphones but they have decent noise-cancelling properties for the price. In addition, they stay on my ears when I'm exercising which is always nice. My only complaint is that the headphones themselves are just a hair too big for my head, so even adjusted to the smallest size/length, they could still be a bit shorter. But because of the way they're built, they still stay stable on my head. I'm pleased with this purchase. I didn't have to spend a lot of my money to get something that works.

Really nice speakers that have wonderful volume control. These speakers work fine. Just remember the price. These aren't Bose or JBL.. They work just like they should.  What can I say, they're speakers.

Needed a Living Room sub for our 5.1 system. had to be somewhat small but pack a good punch.
Harman Kardon AVR1700 receiver, Axiom Audio M2 bookshelf and BIC center channel and couple of small polk audio rears.
once i went online read about a good starting point on this sub, it made my H/K auto setup so much easier. 80 is my crossover start and setup using H/K's LFE sub output. good match.
we get good deep sound (*way better than the cheaper sub we had earlier), it is pretty harmonious with our Axiom and BIC fronts.
still need to do a bit more tweaking as we run more blu ray movies. time for Matrix to be played. have only owned this for one week. so far can't be happier. This is pretty heavy, but not so large that it's hard to position. I have it next to my computer that I use to listen to Amazon streaming MP3 music. My main speakers are NHT Model Twos, and this subwoofer supplies an excellent bottom end to the music. I haven't played it loud yet, but I'm looking forward to trying it out on a movie soundtrack.

The power switch has three positions -- Off, On, and Auto. In the Auto setting, it turns itself on if it senses an incoming signal. When I'm playing music softly, I'm finding that it takes a while to discover that it should turn on. In my case, the subwoofer is sitting next to my desk, and it's not hard to reach the power switch. But keep this in mind if you want to hide it somewhere that would make the power switch hard to reach. (It's near the top of the rear of the cabinet.) There's also a phase switch, with two positions. There's no magic to that; just set it to the position that sounds best. As with all subwoofers, the placement in your room isn't critical, although the subwoofer's sound can be somewhat amplified if you locate it in a corner.

Update: I've had time now to use this with lots of different types of music, as well as TV and movies. The bass is very solid and tight, with no boominess at all. It blends beautifully, with plenty of power for my medium-sized room. This is very musical, adding firm support that's more than just "punch". This is surely one of the best values in powered subwoofers, and I'd buy it again in a heartbeat. It is hard to find a better subwoofer under $200

Overall I am quite happy with this product. I believe the quality is good for the price and hope to use the headphones for quite a long time. The only hitch I had was with the connection. The instructions are fairly clear but I had to do some experimentation to get everything to work with my television. One thing of note which might help ATT Uverse customers -- plug the red and white RCA connectors to the actual Uverse box (at the rear -- Audio Out) rather than to your television. I think this may have been mentioned by another reviewer but I had overlooked it earlier. Plugging into the unit eliminates the static also. One last thing -- I would advise buyers of this product to purchase extra pads for the headphones. Once a style is no longer universally available the replacement pads can be very hard to find. For the $16 it is worth the money and saves grief later on. These are fabulous! A friend told me about them. You can hear everything in these headphones while watching TV- birds, footsteps and all things you don't normally hear on a TV show. Especially good for understanding English speaking PBS shows. Great thing about these is that one person can have them on while watching TV , the sound on the TV can be muted so the other person sleeping doesn't hear the TV. I would highly recommend them. Just plug in and they work. Easy! After 6.5 months the charging dock stopped recharging the headphones batteries.
I am not sure how the 2-year limited warranty works. As I try to start all my reviews with where it's made, this one falls into the Made in China category. It's not an extremely expensive hi-fi unit, eben thou it says it is hi-fi, but for the price the sound quality should a lot better. It's like listening to an am radio station that goes in and out of range. The tuning is not a simple selector switch, but instead it uses a scroll wheel located right by the volume scroll wheel. I'm not sure what genius thought that was a smart location for it, because on a few a occasions I've changed the tuning by mistake. if your TV is like mine with an aux cord out, and no sound system, than you might run into the issue where the TV won't play through its own speakers when the unit is plugged in and your using it. This may be an issue if you wanted to use it as a audio booster if you are hard of hearing and want a separate volume control from that of the TV's speakers. Overall it was just poor experience with the unit. I usually love Sennheiser products, and they used to be made very well, I believe there high end is still that way. but like every company these days they sacrifice a lot trying to cheapen themselves to a price point that everyone can afford. I was very conflicted before buying these headphones as I read the negatives and questioned whether these were as good as the last Sennheiser headphones that just broke. I will say that these perform differently when not charged fully. It is best not to use them before you've left them overnight on the charger. Then you will have less problems with static. You may hear static when you first put them on but as soon as the music or youtube video has started the sound is crystalline. I'm currently listening to some of my favorite music and it could not sound better. So I'm glad I took the chance even when I expected there to be issues. Sennheiser is really as good as AKGs once tuned in. You can also walk around the house with these on and take your music with you. Just charge them before using for the best results.

~The Rebecca Review I have owned many wireless headsets over the years due to long time hearing loss. This is the most expensive of the the lot and I had hoped these would be a better choice. Unfortunately the frequency seems to drift and you are constantly trying to adjust it back to get the volume back. The adjustment wheel is very sensitive and a pain to operate. If the audio stops the unit times out and goes to white noise. I have used ref and infrared units some costing twenty dollars and NONE of them had these problems. Don’t ever try and tell me you get what you pay for. Life is not that simple.

I put a computer in the garage. I needed speakers that were cheap because of their limited (anticipated) use. These are very good, especially for the price. Let's face it, for the money you're not going to get true audiophile quality sound, but...

I have all my music digitized and stored on a NAS. I was just looking for a cost effective (i.e. cheap) way to listen to my music in my bedroom where I have a laptop connected. These are small, very well constructed, nice looking, and nice sounding little speakers. I rated these 4 stars for sound quality considering the price. Just what I was looking for, very happy with them. These should only be purchased if you need portable speakers for a laptop or tablet. The sound is mediocre at best. They are light weight and portable.

If you are looking for an affordable desktop speaker i recommend Creative A250 (about $30) These are great inexpensive speakers. I needed some speakers for my desktop at work and these are great for that. I haven't turned them up a lot since I can't be jamming out at work. But for the price, they are well worth it. Small, compact, easy simple setup. Quality speakers with BIG sound. Expect nothing less from Logitech.

They bought these for us at work. They work so well, thar I bought a pair for home when I telework. They dramatically improve the ability to hear in meetings when using zoom or another software. I would definitely recommend these headphones for both professional and private use. I am very happy with the sound and overall fit. However, the headphones start to hurt on long calls when wearing glasses. Overall it is s great product. I bought these headphones because I thought they would last me a long time and the reviews were great.
The first pair I got at Walmart and those lasted me 2 years and then they stopped working and the latest one I bought on Amazon and thet just lasted me 1 year. I am so disappointed with these. I won't be buying them again. This really works well for Teams calls. The microphone and the noise cancelling in MS Teams seem to work very well, where I have been able to attend meetings and am heard very clearly without too much background noise. Felt like cheap plastic. Came with no original box just a plastic bag, I don’t know if maybe just Logitech sold it in bulk to the seller this way as it was easier for shipping and all for them. However, made me somewhat suspicious it could be a fake as it felt very cheap and other reviewers mentioned the same thing. No other headphones I have ever used have done this and I have used headsets to work on a computer for 10 years. The sides of the headphones just said logi on them. I returned this!

I needed speakers for my computer.  Theses are inexpensive but have a very good sound.  I like that they don't need batteries and use a USB slot on the back of my computer.  They are only about 6.4 inch tall so they don't take up much room on my desk. THESE SPESKERS ARE OK.  THEY SOUND OK.  THE ONLY THING I DON'T LIKE ABOUT THEM IS THAT THE VOLUME CONTROL ARE PUSH BUTTON RATHER THAN DIAL BUTTON. AND YOU HAVE TO HOLD THE SPEAKER IN ORDER TO ADJUST THE VOLUME.  THEY WERE EASY TO CONNECT.  JUST PLUG IN THE USB CABLE. So I ordered these because my laptops music jack was broken.  These plug into your USB port and they worked perfectly for me.  Granted they are not powered so the volume only goes so high...  They aren't loud but they were perfect for my use.  If your looking for loud gaming sound or music you should look for a amplified set of speakers. Returned these speakers because they didn't produce sound loud enough in order to hear anything from my Macbook Pro computer. The sound they projected had a tinny quality that only made the background noises heard and not the speaking voices. I was disappointed because I have always purchased cheap speakers before, but I upgraded finally to ELEGIANT USB Powered Sound Bar Speakers after these failed me and I was not disappointed. The sound bar was three times more expensive, but the sound it produced cannot be beat. I get surround sound quality from my computer and the sound bar is much more compact and sleek than two clunky speakers. In my opinion, the sound bar cannot be beat!

This little radio (and a couple of AAA batteries) is what got me through 2 weeks of no power during Hurricane Sandy. Worth the investment. I primarily wanted a small radio to listen to AM at night and this one turned out to be a challenge because there's no backlight on the

I was looking to replace/upgrade my multimedia speakers without breaking the bank. These speakers fit my price range. I was iffy on buying these because I had never heard of the brand before, but the reviews were pretty positive, so I gave them a shot. Boy, am I glad that I did. They arrived in wonderful condition, as Amazon.com never disappoints when shipping anything. They hook up a bit differently than basic multimedia speakers, but I had no trouble hooking them up. The sound out of these little powerhouses is fantastic. We're listening to Thelonious Monk, and it feels as if we're sitting right at one of his jazz shows way back when. It sounds good with any genre of music. The customizable bass and treble settings, make things nice. You're not put over the top with crazy controls, either. Operation is pretty straightforward. Anyone with a basic knowledge of technology, shouldn't have any problem using these speakers. The only thing that I didn't like is that the remote gave out after only one use. We can't seem to get it to work now. That's the only reason I'm knocking them a star. If you want good bang for your buck, look no further. You won't be disappointed. Volume control feature is not very sophisticated. Bass delivery is on side of box - seems directionally challenged. Easy to set up. Stupid short plugs and wires... So cheap! System arrived quickly and suits my needs. Maybe I should have gotten a Bluetooth system. This is plugged into my TV My last review was a generous one, only because I didn't allow much time to pass before I did my first review. Things have changed. I have purchased four sets of these speaker systems. The very first set I bought for myself, last Christmas and over a year ago died. Amplifier electronics went bad, I think. This was way after the warranty expired but less than one year. I bought one set each prior to any malfunction, for both of my young adults, and another one for myself. The set I bought three weeks ago was dead when it arrived and the only music it made was a very loud buzzing right out of the box. So, I have two speaker set's that don't work and I will pass judgment after I talk with the manufacturer (Eagle) tomorrow. My big worry now is if the speaker sets' I bought my kids will die in short order. All in all, I am not pleased with the longevity of performances of the Eagle Orion. I purchased a set of Eagle Tech sound stage speakers prior to buying the Orion's and, the Eagle tech 140 watt version still sound great. So, I'm going straight to the manufacturer and see if they will do right by me. I will post what the resolution is, good or bad. This whole debacle is really a shame because they are great looking and sounding speakers and I think more often than not, this sort of thing happens for the speed of sales therefore decreasing quality control and inadequate testing prior to shipping. Two out of four in less than one year or 3 weeks means something isn't right with the process. Speaker system arrived today and was straight forward hook up to my 32" flat screen. I give three stars

1 star for quality of sound this little system really boosted the sound of my TV in my living room. You can adjust the base. treble and volume individually to you're listening needs as my living room is 15x18 feet and fills the room with good sound and comes with a remote

1 star for simplicity of hookup to any device i want

1 star for the durability of the system itself and looks great for the price.

I took away two stars for GOOD reasons

The remote is very cheep junk i do not expect to last for more than a few weeks. if you stack four quarters up that's how thick the remote is and it bends easily I am going to try to program a universal remote to this tomorrow

The second star is removed because the buttons on the front are poor quality the first time i touched the volume button it got stuck in and had to gently tap it several times for it to pop back out , I expect the buttons to not last if used every day so again i will try to set up a universal remote for volume control

Over all good sounding system remote needs improvement along with buttons on front

The remote control is handy but only has on/off and volume features which is disappointing because I thought the ability to change bass and trebel would be there as well. Last but not least, I hate the way the remote is attached to the speakers. It has a Y shaped cord so it constantly gets wrapped up in my mouse cord or power cord to my lap top. Speakers are great but the woofer emits a low humming noise as soon as it was plugged in and noise continues throughout usage.

These are small but very clear. Easy to replace my 7 year old JBL computer speakers. Same simple plugs. Logitech, THANK YOU for this great product! Having always had poor speakers for my PC -- until now -- I never realized what great sound could be delivered! All I can say is Wow! I am very impressed by the facts that these speakers are inexpensive, but clearly well-made, and the sound is pure and powerful. Two thumbs up! For the price of the speaker these work well. They are made in china as expected, but still feel well made. These are simple only three wires power, 3.5mm , and the wire joining the two speakers. They are simple to operate with only a volume level control, and are great for the YouTube watcher or some moderate level music. You won't get the same bass out of these as you would with a 2.1 channel sound system, but that is expected. I like Logitech speakers because in my experience they tend to stand behind their product. I had another set of speakers from them that went bad, and after a few questions they sent me a new unit without requiring an RMA for the old ones. Overall if you need a set of basic speakers these are great and reasonably priced. These are great speakers, smaller than the logitech they replaced, and have just as much volume if not more.

At this great price, I always keep a couple of extra sets in my purse for when my kids lose or break their earbuds. The sound is quite good. These are the only earbuds that actually fit in my ear comfortably and don't fall out when I move my head.
I still like the kind that have a behind the ear clip if I run but it isn't convenient if you are taking them on and off alot. These are perfect inexpensive earbuds for everyday use. Fun colors too! New favorite headphones! Absolutely love them.. fit in ears great. Best headphones I've bought in the last year. No more searching!

Great value for the money. The buds go right up behind your tragus really blocking any extra sound. For those of us with a tragus piercing, it does work fine, but my earring starts to ache after maybe 45 minutes. But it does not slip out even with the tragus stud. The wire seemed like poorer quality than I was anticipating--thicker and flat rather than thin and roundish like the more current models--but that is more of a style critique than one of functionality. The headphones have worked well for the few weeks that I have been using it. If you're looking for something that will stay in your ear and block out all other sound, producing high sound quality, this is a great model to get, especially for the price. Only reason I wouldn't give these 5 stars is the input end?(not sure what it's called) The input portion that you would put into the phone is "L" shaped versus "l". I have to buy a new phone case so that I can use the headphones with the case on. Other than that, these headphones are fantastic! Crystal clear sound with minimal volume, and I don't even mind that they are in-ear. They are headphones that perform very poorly with regards to other headphones I have purchased from Amazon. These earbuds have great sound, they fit in my ear comfortably and don't come out unless I want them to. Great value for the price I paid. I have paid over twice as much for similar earbuds and these sound way better. Good headphones for what I need them for, which is the gym. Reasonably priced too. Let me start off by saying that I have used many, many different earbuds and headphones over the years, and these are by FAR the best bang for my buck in terms of quality, durability, and comfort. I've always managed to land jobs where I'm able to listen to audio content throughout my workday, and have consequently spent most of my working hours with at least one earbud tucked into my ears.

I thread these down to my pocket where they are plugged into my iPod full time. No matter how much running, walking, lifting, jumping or moving around I do (and I work as a package delivery guy, which means hundreds of movements and ten miles of walking a day), these things take ages to wear out. Under normal use, I'm sure they'd never need replacing unless you managed to blow out the speaker somehow, or cause blatant damage to them. They don't cut in and out from wear on the jack end or on the headphone ends like some other earbuds, which will give way after being cranked around a bit.

Next, I have to address the comfort of the ergonomically shaped buds themselves. They are formed to fit into ear, with the speaker being offset from the center of the housing. On others, such as the classic white Apple earbuds, the round shape causes me some discomfort and soreness after hours of wear. But these are just fantastic. I wear them for up to 11 hours at a time with no discomfort whatsoever.

Finally, the sound quality. While an audiophile purist will say that they probably don't meet the highest standards in the land, they do a pretty good job. They stand up to much more expensive earbuds, and if you use the proper sized adapter for your ear (three sizes included), the speaker isolates sound very well, so you don't even need any noise-canceling feature. I wear them while driving a diesel truck with the doors open driving down the freeway, and I can hear every word of the audiobook I'm listening to. The treble is good. The bass is excellent for such an inexpensive earbud. And the overall sound quality is going to put other in-ear buds to shame.

For less than ten bucks, there is no better ear bud out there. I've owned three pairs over the last two years, and I would only have needed one if I didn't abuse them so much with daily use and extreme wear. If you want to try these, but would like to keep a microphone feature for hands-free calls, you can get some identical to these with in-line microphone in the Panasonic RPTCM125K model. I got these are my on the gone headphones. They work great Good headphones for my tween son. He likes them. Says they fit well and are comfortable to wear. Now if he can just keep up with them! These earbuds last for pretty long. I am pretty impressed. I think the price is reasonable for the quality

Not much you can say about a mouse except that it works as it's expected. This one feels good in the hand and has a scroll wheel and forward and back buttons, and the battery life is phenomenal. It will run forever on a couple AA batteries. I have three of these now. Also, the wireless receiver is small enough it doesn't protrude from the computer or laptop far enough to get bumped off or broken accidentally. I work full-time from home and have been using this same Logitech mouse for years. When it’s time for a replacement, I do look to see what other options are out there…but I just keep coming back to this one.

It’s comfortable in my hand and responds well to my touch. The only reason I need to replace it is because I often eat at my desk and sometimes that’s hard on a mouse. Also, when you consider how much time we spend using a mouse, the surface is just bound to wear down.

I like the size…I have tried the mini versions but that size isn’t practical for me working all day at a computer.

I probably don’t use all the features…just the wheel and left/right clicks. It rolls nicely and the battery life lasts quite a while. I like the little green light on the top to tell me it still has a charge.

I use a basic mouse pad with a built-in wrist rest and my hand and arm do not feel any strain. The rubberized grip really helps me hold onto it comfortably.

I have seen this mouse in other patterns but I stick with this dark gray version. I have a black desk and I would just prefer to keep everything monochromatic, since my office is in my home.

Definitely plug and play once you put in the USB receiver.

I think this is a quality item for the price and I will continue to purchase, as needed. I highly recommend its reliability. It's comfortable for my medium sized lady hands (I can rest my hand on the mouse) and I love the features (scroll wheel, forward and back buttons), but like others have said the scrolling is choppy. You have to really focus it to get it on an window close button for example. That said, it's my best choice for a Logitech unifying receiver mouse. The M325 worked very well but was too small for my hand.

I just wish it worked as well as my Logitech MediaPlay mouse I bought a decade ago. Unfortunately that has a giant USB receiver and I work on a Macbook with only two USB ports and also use a wireless keyboard.

Ugh, no perfect solution for me.

Got this speaker (Logitech USB Laptop Speaker Z305) for my Mac to amp up the sound during movies ... and just love it.  It attaches super easily, has great sound, easy-access on/off, and volume controls on the speaker which are readily accessible while it's on the pc.  Highly recommend.  Please note that I purchased this in 2011 when the price was $39.99 (just noticed Dec 29, 2012 price is now over $100!) I bought these speakers a few years ago for a laptop I had that only had 1 little speaker built into it and this speaker has worked great even now as I have them hooked up to the store laptop were I work. I only paid $45 brand new from an online source ( not sure now who it was it was so long ago ) but I can say that they still look like I just bought them and pulled them from the package. I don't understand how these can be listed and sold for $289.99 when they are only worth at best $45 which even when I bought them for $45 I thought they were a tad bit overpriced then but for the extreme price I found them for now is just a total rip off cause even though they sound pretty good for a little speaker set they are no where near worth $289.99. For that price I would buy an entire 6.1 surround system and hook my laptop to it, OH! I already did that for $150 and I still use these and only paid $45 when I bought them a few years ago. My laptop built-in speakers are totally inadequate, so based on customer reviews for this speaker, I purchased it for my computer.  "Easy" to install is just that - even I could do it! Clip the speaker to the top of the screen, plug the USB into a port on your computer, and listen!  Speaker quality is terrific, a great range for loudness, and the sound is extremely clear.  It was a great buy!

amazing headset, but with this crippling flaw they are useless in dense population areas. MY HISTORY WITH THIS PRODUCT:
I've owned this headset for almost a full year. Technically, I've had two of them, since the boom mic snapped off the first one and had it replaced. I use these every day, for multiple hours and a variety of uses (VoIP calls, gaming, music, and movies).

PROS:
The audio quality, when it is working, is good. The bass in 7.1 mode is great, and the overall surround sound is pretty convincing. They are comfortable and rechargeable via USB.

CONS:
The biggest problem here is the wireless connection. Both headsets I owned suffered from this same problem - they would frequently just restart or lose the signal and reconnect. The process takes about 3-5 seconds each time, and sometimes you get multiple restarts in a row. It doesn't sound too bad until it happens when you're watching a movie and you have to quickly pause or rewind a bit because you suddenly couldn't hear anything they were saying (which also completely pulls you out of the movie), or when it drops out in the middle of a phone conversation, or drops out at the worst possible moment in a game... It happens probably two dozen times a day, if not more. At first, I didn't care too much about it, but the first time you have it drop out 3 times in a matter of a single minute, it's simply maddening. Imagine going randomly deaf for several seconds throughout every day of your life, and you'll get a sense of what it's like.

If I could simply plug the cable in and it would use the USB cable to transmit the audio instead of wireless, that would be perfect, but when it's plugged in, it simply charges the internal battery - you still get audio interruptions all the time. The interruptions will also reset the "mute" status on the mic, which can be troublesome if you're intentionally muted on a conference call and suddenly your mic is on and people hear you eating lunch.

Second problem is that the power button is a bit flaky. If the headset is plugged in via USB and powered off, sometimes it will not power on unless you unplug the headset and THEN power it on (and then you can plug it back in to continue charging). I thought it was a defect in my first headset until the same thing happened with the second one.

A minor third problem is that the boom mic is a little flimsy on the construction. I am careful with my toys, but it still cracked and finally snapped off one day when I was lowering the mic to use it, and that was only a few months into owning it.

OVERALL:
If they would fix the wireless, I would rate this 4 stars in a heartbeat. If they fixed the power button, it would go up to 5. That said, the G35 seems to be the G930 but wired, and cheaper. The number of times that I've wanted to really make good use of the wireless (go to another room and keep the audio going) is far less frequent than the dozens upon dozens of times that the audio cuts out, so it's just an unacceptable point for me, since that is what this headset is about.

This is a combined review of two of the lowest cost “Active Noise Cancelling” earbuds on Amazon:
[[ASIN:B004K09H32 Audio-Technica ATH-ANC23 QuietPoint Active Noise-Cancelling In-Ear Headphones]]
[[ASIN:B00SA5JCWO Egghead 1010 - Active Noise Cancelling Earbuds with Travel Pouch]]

PRICE
The price difference as of May, 2015 was $14 with Audio-Technica being the more expensive unit.

IN THE BOX
Both products contain:
--Earbuds
--Multiple silicone earbud cups
--Airline headset adapter
--Carrying Pouch

Audio-Technica contains in addition:
--Battery
--Pair of foam earbud cups. Not memory foam, just normal foam. I have not tried these.

Egghead:
--Mute button: In addition to the ANC on/off switch, Egghead has a nice mute button that turns off Noise Cancellation while it is pressed down.

SOUND QUALITY
I am not an audiophile so the sound from both headsets were good to me but the difference comes when you factor in the fit of the earbuds.

FIT
Both sets sit deeply in your ear and from pictures of both products, you will see that beyond the earbud, they have a circular piece before the actual connection to the wires.
--Egghead: The earbuds are attached straight to the circular piece so the fit is actually straight out away from your ears.
--Audio-Technica: The earbuds are angled forward so the circular piece actually serves as an anchor that sits nicely in your ear lobe and further cuts out outside noise. The additional foam earbud cup may make the difference for some people when it comes to a comfortable fit.
--Kids: I purchased these for a trip that the family will take. The kids usually have a hard time with normal earbuds not fitting in very well but they were able to keep the Audio-Technica earbuds in using the smallest earbud cups. The kids are 6 and 9.

NOISE REDUCTION
Here is the main event. I want to make a few points about Active Noise Cancelling: --Noise cancellation filters are designed to cancel out lower pitched, repeating noises like airplane engine rotors and car tires on a road, but it will not cancel out high or mid-range sounds like human voice. The same engine rotor and road noise also contain components of higher pitched sounds so NC filters will not cut out the noise completely.
--Using Noise Cancellation often feels like being underwater with your ears popping. It is a discomfort that you would have to get used to. The greater the cancellation effect, the greater the discomfort. Be prepared for this if you haven’t used NC before.
--ANC only works IF the inverted noise wave can overpower the noise coming in. If you are using a lawn mower and the noise it makes overpowers the “anti noise” because you’re standing right in back of the motor, you will not hear a big difference in the Noise Reduction effects.

Ok, so on with it. The Audio-Technica claims to reduce 90% of noise. I don’t have anything to confirm the claim but if we assume the Audio-Technica(AT) to be at 90%, my own assessment of the Egghead’s (Egg) noise reduction effects would be around 50-60%.

--Computer Fan Noise: Egg reduces the noise to slightly audible but you’d need to use toggle the mute button on it to really tell. AT completely removes the noise.
--Clothes Dryer: Egg takes the “edge” off the noise produced. You can still hear most of the noise standing about 3 feet away from the dryer. AT takes the bass tones completely out of the noise while leaving the higher pitched metal friction and buttons hitting the tumbler noise. In effect, with the AT, standing only 3 feet away, it sounds like you are actually 20 feet away.

So in conclusion, you have probably guessed that I think the additional cost of the Audio-Technicas are worth it. In addition to the benefits mentioned above, I have recently been able to get a great deal on a pair of [[ASIN:B00UETOW4C Harmon/Kardon SOHO II NC]] on ebay. The noise reduction effects of the Audio-Technicas equal or maybe even exceeds those of the Harmon/Kardons. You get two types of noise cancelling with this. First, there's some noise blocking just from having these stuck in your ears. Then the active noise cancelling works quite well. But you have to have them stuck in your ears really firmly, which isn't too easy for me. I suppose it all depends on the shape of your ears. You get several sets of tips, but none of them seem to fit me quite right.

The active noise cancelling works better than I expected. It does a better job with low rumbles, like aircraft noise. It's not so good with voices, but it does give you a little bit of reduction there too. I use them in my office, in a somewhat busy environment.

The sound quality is very pleasing, but it doesn't have the sparkling highs or very deep lows that you get with more expensive earphones or earbuds. Nevertheless, the sound is smooth and well balanced, so it's comfortable to listen to.

For the price, I'm pretty happy. The earbuds are very large, if you have small ears. The other issue is that the callers I spoke to reported a lot of background noise, even with the noise cancellation turned on.

No point for the universal remote then, is there? Returning this item for a refund. Keep trying Logitech. And my requirement is to have two remote controls even if I have one that is a central hub.

This headphones works good enough. I bought this because the Jabra headphones seem to always cut out. I bought the Jabra because they can support 2 devices at one time. These however can not. Let me start by saying I don't use the cell phone features of these headphones, so this review is not all encompassing.

That said, I was a little disappointed in these headphones. Although the sound quality is good, the build quality and attention to detail in design could be better. The control buttons on the right ear are difficult to use as you can't easily feel with your finger where one starts and another begins, You just have to press in the general area, which is not very reassuring. The buttons themselves have no raised symbols or any physical element you can touch to let you know you're on a button, let alone the correct one.

The build quality is not the best. The control buttons fit together less tightly than other Bluetooth headphones I've used. The main play/pause/on/off/pairing button, located in the center of the right earphone in particular seems loose and misaligned.

The functions of the buttons work well enough. However, with some functions, there is no audio feedback. Having used other headsets that provide a short beep each time a button is pressed, I was a little confused when I first tried these - I'd press pause and the audio would just stop, with no beep. I suppose some users would find this preferable though. Some of the button functions, such as play/pause, are not instantaneous. There's a slight delay (about a second) between the time you press it and the time the audio actually plays or pauses. I've experienced this with other Bluetooth headsets and it seems to be a common annoyance.

Because the fit is somewhat tight, getting the earphones on requires a little manipulation. I often find I have to guide the tip of my ear into the space between the neckband (the part that holds the earpieces and wraps around your neck) and the earpiece.This is mainly due to the padding on the earpieces. Once the headphones are on though, they've not uncomfortable. However, a little more space between the neckband and the top of the earpieces would be an improvement. Wearing the headphones lying down or with your head against the back of a seat is not uncomfortable for the most part.

The charging port is has a rubber cover. Although it serves a purpose and some might find this helpful, I find it just gets in the way and will likely fall off. The charging cable is VERY short - about 3 feet, and it comes with no AC adapter, so you'll need to plug it into a USB port for charging - or acquire an adapter so you can use an electrical outlet. Due to the shortness of the cord, it will likely be inconvenient for use with some outlets.

Attaching the charging cord is somewhat difficult. This is to be expected, I guess, due to the micro-USB size of the plug that goes into the ear piece. The end of the cord that plugs into the ear piece is tapered on one side, so there's some visual indication of which way it should go in, but it's always a pain trying to insert these kinds of plugs, no matter what the device. I haven't used the headphones for any great length of time, so I can't comment on the battery life at this time.

The fact that these headphones can fold up to a fairly small size is nice and may be helpful to some when traveling. Typically, I wear them while walking or taking public transportation, so no real advantage for me.

As a musician with a home studio, I needed some new headphones to track with. These came with good reviews, so I decided to give them a try. Good move on my part... they have a good uncolored sound, cover the ears completely and even come with 2 cables (1 coiled, 1 straight). I do have a big head (size xxl hat) and proportional ears. I wouldn't say these are "roomy", but they do just cover my ears and seal around them nicely to minimize any sound leaking. I was trying to choose. Sony MDR-V6 Sony MDR-7506, ATH-M30, ATH-M40... I looked at everything. I found a youtube channel, which plays direct from CD sample, then crossover in sync to various model headphones resampling the sound from the each headphone as it's placed over a foam head. - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sj69-mWHV3E - The point is, they are trying to reproduce what is heard. Also, I found another youtube channel of a guy who shows various headphones sampled through a graphic analyzer, showing the frequency response.

All headphones add something to the signal. So what you hear on one model isn't the same, with another. But of all the head phones, the ATH-M40x was identical in sound reproduction to the original music. You couldn't tell the difference. Why is this important? Two reasons, if you are an audio engineer, you will have a truer sound, what you hear, is what you will get. It goes both ways, what you listen to, will be what the sound engineer intended for you to hear.

For music with base, it has good presence, and you can hear details that sound muddy on other head phones. I have been listening to a lot of head phones. You do understand muddy and clarity, once you hear it.

With that said, and having spent some time, in store sampling, (note: I must say that the Sonys are really good too. I tried and liked the MDR-V55 as well. It's a DJ headset so it's a bit more base. I felt they were very clear and better than the MDR-X05 hands down.)

The ATH-M40x, has removable cables. They are field repairable. And you can choose between three different cables, although two come in the box.

They are son tested and approved. Now I have to keep them locked up, joking. They are well built. Some say the ATH-M50x is better. It's also said the M50x sound the same as last year's model, and the M40x sound as good as last year's M50 model too. Which is it? The M40x is specifically flat sounding for audio engineering. The M50x is targeted for the audiophile, with a V shape EQ. The M40x is in the sweet spot, unless you have money to burn.

They are a bit tight, but this may be alleviated by exchanging the ear pads with velour pads. This exchange compromises the sound profile a little bit, but makes them more comfortable. You be the judge. I am still waiting to do it myself.

This BOSE SOUNDLINK COLOR BLUETOOTH SPEAKER may not be the ideal portable speaker for serious audiophiles--because it has no treble/base buttons, only volume buttons--but I love mine. The volume is controlled by the device the speaker is connected to, or by the plus/minus volume buttons on the speaker itself. The speaker also has an Aux button for the direct cable connection, and a Skip button that lets you go forward or backward in your music selections.

This Bose portable speaker can support two Bluetooth-connected devices at once, so you can switch between two devices (e.g., an iPad and a Kindle Fire) without repeating the pairing process every time. A great feature! The speaker automatically connects with the last-connected Bluetooth device, and switches devices when you press the Bluetooth button. The speaker's voice prompts help you with pairing, and tell you which two devices are currently paired. The voice prompts can be disabled, if you wish.

This Bose speaker is definitely an improvement over the speakers built into my old Sony Bravia TV. Voices are much clearer--including the dialogue from British TV shows--and the sound is far richer. Of course, using this speaker instead of a TV sound bar is only a temporary solution, because the speaker needs regular recharging. When fully charged, it delivers sound for many hours (up to 8) and outlasts the charge on the [[ASIN:B004B8GF7Y TaoTronics® Bluetooth Transmitter]] that I added to my non-Bluetooth-enabled TV.

Whether the TaoTronics transmitter was connected to the TV's headphone jack or to the TV's AV ouputs, this speaker paired instantly. However, when the TV transmitter was connected to the AV outputs, the speaker produced some static unless it was positioned close to the TV. When the TV transmitter was connected to the headphone jack, the speaker produced no static at all, no matter where it was positioned (within the Bluetooth range).

This Bose speaker charges quickly with the included AC adapter and USB cable. Pressing the speaker's power button produces a battery indicator that glows red, amber, or green to indicate the current level of charge. The speaker is lightweight enough to carry around in a backpack or tote bag. There is a case available (see [[ASIN:B00NJGRKG4 Bose SoundLink Color carry case]]), but I don't think a case is needed, because the speaker seems to be sturdily constructed. Totally worth the money to purchase. My husband and I use this speaker all the time. The sound is terrific and it's easily portable. Battery life is pretty good, bluetooth range is solid. On the other hand, my cat knocked it off a small table onto a hard floor and it simply bounced and didn't (literally) miss a beat. My husband loves it. Sure beats the Shark speaker I bought him. Absolutely love this speaker. Easy set up, great sound, portable. A must have!

I got this on a black friday deal and have loved it so far. Essentially this is a little computer. You can connect the WI-Fi to your house link and use a word processor on Google docs. If you connect a bluetooth keyboard, you've got a laptop. I don't know why people would spend hundreds of dollars getting a laptop (or why school districts go with ipads) when you can get this for under $50. At this price, you can't afford not to have one (because when the kids demand to get on your tablet, they can beat on this instead of the $800 work issued device they want). If you just want a tablet for basic things, this is for you! If you're looking for an excellent tablet and e-reader at a great price, look no further. While there are things that it lags with (like playing the Pokemon trading card game, which last I knew, needed to be sideloaded) it does a lot of other things really well. Great experience with watching videos, and reading comics or manga.

If you're into hacking your devices, this tablet (well, the 2015 version that I have) does a really good job of running a clean Nexus rom, which gives you a stock Android experience, and access to the Google play store. I have to say, that was probably the best thing I've done with it so far.

Expandable storage allows you to carry an entire library with you on the go to make sure that you will never run out of things to do. I keep a 128gb micro SD card in mine, but I wouldn't be surprised if you could slot in a larger card, even though it's only officially rated for up to 128gb.

What i'd like to see change for the 2018 version (assuming they do a revamp) would be full 1080p resolution, a snapdragon octacore processor clocked around 2ghz (my free ZTE Blade Zmax has one, and I can't imagine it would be too expensive for them to use it in the fire tablet as well, if even free phones have them now) and 2-3 gb of ram. If Amazon would just do these 3 little upgrades, this tablet would be unbeatable. I wouldn't even mind a mild price bump ($70-80 instead of $50) if these upgrades happened. I would also like to see a future version either running full stock Android OS, or released with the option to unlock the bootloader somehow, to facilitate diy development and cutom roms. But I know that's just asking too much.

If you're looking for a great tablet at an even better price, the Fire 7" is a great choice.

I am an Amazon Prime customer and all my music is on Amazon streaming. Both ease of use (on Amazon Music/Pandora, etc. only) and sound in one word, Superb! Not so! I just listened back to back.

Without intending to compare them, I got my UEBoom to play while I setup the marvelous SOAIY Aurora projector (upgraded version), and in the back of my mind notice the music, not played very loudly because it's nighttime, was rather muddy; I think it wows people for its volume and base. On a whim I switched to my new Amazon Tap received today (I hadn't much time to experiment with it) and... Wow! Fantastic sound quality! Much more enjoyable than the popular UEBoom.

Better flat frequency response like a pair of reference headphones (like the Sony Studio MV6 I prefer), more clear definition and detail, not muddy, better treble response (I don't mean tinny or lack of bass), and bass rivaling that of UEBoom. Oh, the main thing I noticed also, which confused me at first, is the wide stereo dispersion (?), um, I mean wide field effect and stereo separation. I literally looked at the cylinder puzzled as to what I was hearing and mentally verifying only this device was on and was the source of the sound I was hearing.

The UEBoom always sounded merely monaural from one sourcepoint; this sounded like surround sound effect applied to a two-speaker (not 5.1+) tv. I was amazed at what my senses were reporting to me. Okay, I'm going to say it, to my ears, and I have a class D amplifier and 5 pairs of quality headphones of different brands, the sound of this Amazon Tap is superior, right out of the box. I was amazed. And of course streaming directly sans device is certainly more convenient. It "just works". (After connecting to your Wi-Fi network.)

I learned to say "playlist rock", since I have a playlist named rock, or it will play all my Amazon music in the genre "rock". I did ask for the weather after entering my zip code through the Alexa app, which I dislike, and it responded with detailed information. Luckily music playback works directly without a need for app use. I will now mention this superior sound quality is half the price of it's aforementioned similar-sized competitor. I'm now really glad I bought it :)
***

It couldn't find a track in my music library, I checked title of track and found it instantly on my Fire, but the Tap still couldn't find it; everything I've tried to do with it either completely fails, or I resort to a different device because it's quicker and more convenient. So... I own both the tower and now several dots. Of course the dots are more reasonably priced, however, the speaker ability is really where it's vastly different. If you have never used Alexa I would highly recommend you give it a try. The speaker is ok but I added another speaker for music.just wish it had a off switch. I am very happy with my dotty! Plugged right into my home network and became the boss of the house! The sound is really booming for such a little cutie! Love the fact that it connects to my bluetooth speaker so nicely! I ordered a three pack because I wanted one for my music room, living room and one for my girlfriend. Set up was super simple for the basics - connecting to a bluetooth speaker, your calendar (I use google's calendar), and a music source. For the latter I use Pandora and that, too, was simple.

The subtracted star is because while I own a few thousand dollars worth of MP3 albums that I purchased from Amazon, I cannot access them. Apparently you can only stream music from Amazon's cloud if you have Prime, and even then I am not sure that you can access any of your own music that resides in their cloud. To me that is a fail, and an indication that the business and requirements analysts who assisted in the development of this device do not fully understand customer requirements at a very basic level. Another nit is the iHeart Radio music source that is plain confusing to use.

Some other areas where this would be a LOT more useful is to have the ability to set up more than one route for traffic (currently I can only identify a single route, home-to-work or back, whereas I am frequently traveling from one place to the other and traffic conditions for those trips would be very helpful. The same for the calendar: you can get all events for a single day, but not for a week, or weekend so you still have to fire up a calendar app on your phone, tablet or computer if you want to get a sense of how busy you will be over a period longer than a day.

Still, for fifty bucks each - plus the discount for purchasing a three pack - this is a decent device that has proven to be surprisingly useful in my home. My girlfriend instantly took to hers too. In the week or so that I have been using it I find that I am growing increasingly dependent on mine for streaming music from Pandora, looking up quick information while I am reading or watching a documentary, and letting me know what is on my calendar for a specific day.

I have one of mine connected via bluetooth to a [[ASIN:B019PGACR0 LD Systems MAUI 5 Channel PA System]], and my girlfriend has hers connected to a [[ASIN:B00W8O6MJO Creative Sound Blaster Roar 2 Portable NFC Bluetooth Speaker]], both of which greatly out perform the larger Echo. However I also use my other Dot with just its integrated speaker and it is more than adequate, even for streaming music since I have it on an end table.

Overall, for the current fifty bucks this is a bargain (warts notwithstanding), and while I purchased mine more out of curiosity all three have proven to be useful and practical. The speaker is too tinny sounding for anything other than the alexa voice, but I have it paired to an existing quality bluetooth speaker that I owned, which was my plan all along, and I'm satisfied with that. If you don't have an existing external bluetooth speaker, I'd go with the full sized echo instead. I've listened to that speaker several times and it is pretty good. Alexa is great! She answers your questions, tell you the weather, controls your Bluetooth speakers, can control your lights or electronics with added technology. She has her own free games you can play with the family on Alexa. i love my Echo Dot but i am still learning but right out of the box she can do all the basic things you want. the possibilities are endless and there are more things added all the time for the Echo dot. i have it hooked up to my JBL Extreme Bluetooth speaker and it is wonderful. i know the time is coming that almost everyone will have one because it is definitely the future. i have 4 of these Dots in my house now, they are great. Lazy i know, but i'm just so tired at the end of the day!

Easy to use - great battery life - pretty good sound for such a small speaker! What else could you want?? Definitely worth the money. This Bluetooth speaker is the best I’ve ever run across! My son bought one, and I as SO impressed that I bought one, too! I use it with 2 iPad mini’s and my iPhone XR, and my son uses it on his Android phone, with the same great results. The charge lasts forever and the quality is amazing!! {And no, I am NOT being paid for this review. What you read is what I mean.} Given the quality of this speaker, the price is incredible! I own the A3143 Premium Stereo Bluetooth speaker (2x10W=20W) which sounds great, but it doesn't have a microphone or the longer battery life of this lower-cost A3102 SoundCore speaker (2x3W=6W). The features and sound characteristics are different, but which is the better choice depends on personal preference. To me based on sound quality alone, the A3143 wins hands down. The bass is stronger (more power is required to drive the lower frequencies than the higher frequencies), but I also find overall frequency response to be more balanced and accurate for instruments and vocals. For either speaker, I'd recommend using an EQ app to set the frequency response and spatial effects to your preference (I use Bass EQ from Coocent). Interestingly, the maximum volume level for both the A3143 and this A3102 SoundCore are about the same.

The A3102 has a brighter sound overall. The A3102 is good as a general purpose speaker, and it is excellent to use with a cell phone. The A3102 microphone (which the A3143 doesn't have) and speaker quality for voice calling are crisp and clear. My dad who can't hear very well often could not understand me on my cell phone handset or its speakerphone, but had no problem when I used the A3102.

So for long battery life, good overall music speaker, and particularly for use as a microphone/speakerphone for voice calls, A3102 is a good choice. For best music reproduction, the A3143. For either, Anker's quality and customer support are among the best in the industry. First off, I am not an audiophile. This is a review from a simple person who wanted music at work.

I am a Rural Carrier for the United Stated Postal Service. I deliver mail in an LLV truck and these vehicles are basically mobile tin cans. Every panel rattles, making for quite an unpleasant environment, audio wise. I tried playing music directly off my phone, but alas my speakerphone is only so loud and is constantly drowned out by the LLV.

So, I researched Bluetooth speakers and, based on the reviews and popularity, recently purchased two:
-[[ASIN:B016XTADG2 Anker SoundCore Bluetooth Speaker with 24-Hour Playtime, 66-Foot Bluetooth Range & Built-in Mic, Dual-Driver Portable Wireless Speaker with Low Harmonic Distortion and Superior Sound - Black]]
-[[ASIN:B01LZV6TYQ OontZ Angle 3 PLUS Splashproof Bluetooth Speaker - Designed & Engineered by Cambridge SoundWorks for Richer Bass, HD Sound, and 30-Hour Playtime, 10W+ Power, Water Resistant, Portable Wireless Speaker]]

The Anker SoundCore is being returned while I am keeping the OontZ Angle 3 Plus and here is why.

I tested both speakers in my home at first. My very first impression, out of the box:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - was nice to touch and just felt solid and very well built.
Anker SoundCore - just felt like a simple lightweight brick. It really didn't give the impression of longevity or durability.

The set-up guides were quite different from each other.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Extremely easy to read, follow and understand (remember, I am not a music nut lol. This was my first time ever using a Bluetooth speaker and was in completely uncharted territory.) It was all in English, and only English and the diagrams were detailed and made the entire set-up process seamless and carefree.
Anker SoundCore - This guide was very hard to follow. It is printed in darn near every language, in tiny print and the diagrams were quite small as well. I ultimately did get the speaker paired with my phone and figured out what buttons did what, but it took nearly 15 minutes to do so.

Bluetooth Pairing
With both speakers and my phone lined up on a table (well within the proximity specified in each set-up guide), both speakers paired, however:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - MUCH faster in pairing (mere seconds!).
Anker SoundCore - took nearly two minutes to complete the pairing process.

Pause/Play Button
Since I dismount to deliver packages to a customer's door routinely on my route, I really need to have a simply way to pause my music. I really like how both speakers offer this function on directly on the units, saving me from having to handle my phone.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - I barely press the Play/Pause button and the speaker immediately reacts. There is NO hesitation.
Anker SoundCore - I press the Play/Pause button and there is a delay of about 5 seconds.. just long enough to make me think I didn't press hard enough and reach to do it again only for the speaker to finally react.

Volume/Overall Playback Quality
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Wow. Just wow. It is truly unbelievable to hear such full sound, and bass(!), coming from such a small unit. I found myself perfectly pleased with the output without ever reaching max volume on the speaker itself. So I am looking forward to how well it will work in my LLV during my first road test. As for now, I am thoroughly impressed!
Anker SoundCore - I maxed out the volume on my phone and the speaker and was just not impressed. If I could guess, I'd say the max output this speaker achieved was only about 25% more than my speakerphone alone (while the OontZ Angle 3 Plus blew it out of the water with close to double, if not more, output than my speakerphone alone).
I also noted some kind of distortion or interference type background sound with the Anker SoundCore at mid volume and above.

Speakerphone/Mic
I was able to answer an incoming phone call on both units as described in each set-up guide. The quality of in-call sound on each speaker differed:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - My husband's (the caller) voice was crisp and clear, as if he was sitting talking right next to me. There was no distortion or feedback out of the speaker. Husband reported nothing but a clear voice on his phone.
Anker SoundCore - Husband's voice was clear, but echoed horribly. No matter what volume level I used. There was no distortion (I was expecting this given the distortion with the music playback) bu the continuous echoing is a major issue for me. Husband reported a slight "faded" type of echo on his phone.

Road Test (in my LLV)
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - The sound is amazing in the truck! Thinking I would need it, I maxed the volume on both the speaker and my phone then pressed play on my music. Well, I certainly don't need max volume. I reduced the volume on both the speaker and my phone and found a very happy medium output. This speaker performs perfectly in the loud, rattling setting of a USPS LLV.. even while bouncing down rural dirt two tracks and washboard gravel roads. I am extremely pleased with this tiny speaker.
Anker Soundcore - Even with maxed volume settings, I could not get this speaker to perform anywhere near as well as the OontZ Angle 3 Plus. It had volume and was loud enough to hear over the vehicle's own noise, however the distortion/interference mentioned earlier was still present and in the truck during the road test it had what I would describe as an echoing effect on the music, specifically the singers' voices. It just wasn't clear. (I hope that makes sense.)

Battery Life/Listen While Charging
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - So far, the battery life is impressive. After receiving it, I charged it overnight (as recommended). I then had it connected to my phone for about an hour of home testing. Turned it off and I next used it at work on a Saturday.. had it powered on and connected to my phone and actively playing music for about 5.5 hours. I then used it again on Monday (much longer and busier days in the USPS, FYI).. had it on, connected and active continuously for nearly 9 hours. I have yet to see the low battery light come on. I plan to see just how many days of work I can get out of a single charge.
Anker Soundcore - I have no information for this section on this speaker since I am returning it.

Exterior/Cleaning
At first, I had the OontZ Angle 3 Plus setting on the dashboard of the LLV. This didn't last more than two stops. Despite having the four rubber "feet", the speaker still slid around causing more of a distraction than I would like. I ended up setting it on top of my personal bag, in a bin by my feet with the speaker facing up. This move really helped my piece of mind, knowing it will not go anywhere. This speaker has a soft rubber exterior. It is quite nice and feels luxurious, however... this exterior attracts all dust particles within 50 feet! USPS LLVs are *not* known for being the cleanest and even though I moved the speaker from the dust-ridden dashboard to a bin, it was still slathered with dust and dirt by the end of my route. I figured it was a fair trade, sacrificing the appearance for the gain of having decent music. But.. I got home and went to clean it. I will tell you, my expectations of this working were very low. I didn't think the dust would come off that supple rubber. But with a wet paper towel and a few slow wipes, it did. So, it can be cleaned up!

Case
I did purchase the case for this speaker ([[ASIN:B01NBDY6VP [Official] OontZ Angle 3 Plus Bluetooth Portable Speaker Carry Case, Neoprene with Aluminum Carabiner, reinforced zipper, by Cambridge SoundWorks [NOT FOR OontZ Angle 3]]]). I was mainly wanting a safe way to transport and store the speaker, but after reading the other reviews I was hoping I would be able to keep it clean in the case and still enjoy my music on my route. I received the case and used it yesterday. The case is extremely nice and I appreciate the interior mesh pocket. I have no need for it now, but I'm sure it will come in handy if I ever take this speaker on vacation and need to take the charging cables along. As for playback while in the case? Yeah, it was terribly muffled. It didn't work for me as it apparently has for others. Yet, the case itself is exactly what I was wanting for taking it to and from work. It is not as thickly padded as I would have expected, however it does protect the speaker.

Overall, for my specific purpose and intended use for a Bluetooth speaker, the Anker SoundCore simply won't cut it. However, it is still a nice speaker and will perhaps fit your needs perfectly. After all, most people don't drive LLVs and have the same high demands that go along with that. For me, the OontZ Angle 3 Plus is what I'll be bopping down the road to, mailbox to mailbox.

Happy hunting! Hope this review helps you out! UPDATE: This speaker, like every Anker product I've owned, is quality!! I charge on Sunday night, use it average 4 hours a day, and the charge lasts a whole 6 days if not the entire week. Rarely does the charge expire before I put it back on to charge on Sunday night (if it does it is Sunday morning). [[VIDEOID:90e56caf53bb9127a941c450bd417db8]] A battery-powered radio receiver is a good piece of equipment to have on hand when there is an emergency. It can be used to receive important information when there is no power otherwise available. This particular receiver works well and it has the distinction of being one of the smallest receivers I have ever used. It is about the size of a cell phone and it is able to receive shortwave signals as well as AM & FM stations.

This unit is small enough to fit in a pocket and is comparable in size to my iPhone 6 in its case. This makes it ideal for packing along on a trip or keeping someplace where it can be out of the way but ready in an emergency. In my opinion, the size is one of the strongest selling points.

Turning it on by the switch does not turn on receiving. This turns on only the power to the LCD and from there the radio can be turned on by holding down the on/off button on the front. This is an interesting way to make sure the radio is not accidentally powered on, though it is slightly inconvenient. This feature suggests the ideal behind this radio is primarily emergency readiness.

There are a number of ranges set for AM, FM and shortwave on this radio that correspond to different locales. Operable range in one country may be very different than in another, and by separating these out into preset ranges enables changing the suitability for a locale a matter of pressing a button rather than tracking down a new device. This makes traveling with this radio very workable.

After turning it on I have had no issue with finding stations on each appropriate frequency range, though it was easiest finding FM stations due to the prevalence of such in the area where I live.

This is an interesting little radio. It works well, and it is able to pick up stations in different regions by simply changing the available range to scan. The size makes it easy to take with you. Though it is most clearly useful as an emergency radio it works well as a general purpose radio too. The price is nice too, making this an easy radio to recommend.

When see you're buying Bose and the $200 price, you automatically think you're going to get a crystal clear, high quality sound from this soundbar. But you don't get that.

It was all in English, and only English and the diagrams were detailed and made the entire set-up process seamless and carefree.
Anker SoundCore - This guide was very hard to follow. It is printed in darn near every language, in tiny print and the diagrams were quite small as well. I ultimately did get the speaker paired with my phone and figured out what buttons did what, but it took nearly 15 minutes to do so.

Bluetooth Pairing
With both speakers and my phone lined up on a table (well within the proximity specified in each set-up guide), both speakers paired, however:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - MUCH faster in pairing (mere seconds!).
Anker SoundCore - took nearly two minutes to complete the pairing process.

Pause/Play Button
Since I dismount to deliver packages to a customer's door routinely on my route, I really need to have a simply way to pause my music. I really like how both speakers offer this function on directly on the units, saving me from having to handle my phone.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - I barely press the Play/Pause button and the speaker immediately reacts. There is NO hesitation.
Anker SoundCore - I press the Play/Pause button and there is a delay of about 5 seconds.. just long enough to make me think I didn't press hard enough and reach to do it again only for the speaker to finally react.

Volume/Overall Playback Quality
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Wow. Just wow. It is truly unbelievable to hear such full sound, and bass(!), coming from such a small unit. I found myself perfectly pleased with the output without ever reaching max volume on the speaker itself. So I am looking forward to how well it will work in my LLV during my first road test. As for now, I am thoroughly impressed!
Anker SoundCore - I maxed out the volume on my phone and the speaker and was just not impressed. If I could guess, I'd say the max output this speaker achieved was only about 25% more than my speakerphone alone (while the OontZ Angle 3 Plus blew it out of the water with close to double, if not more, output than my speakerphone alone).
I also noted some kind of distortion or interference type background sound with the Anker SoundCore at mid volume and above.

Speakerphone/Mic
I was able to answer an incoming phone call on both units as described in each set-up guide. The quality of in-call sound on each speaker differed:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - My husband's (the caller) voice was crisp and clear, as if he was sitting talking right next to me. There was no distortion or feedback out of the speaker. Husband reported nothing but a clear voice on his phone.
Anker SoundCore - Husband's voice was clear, but echoed horribly. No matter what volume level I used. There was no distortion (I was expecting this given the distortion with the music playback) bu the continuous echoing is a major issue for me. Husband reported a slight "faded" type of echo on his phone.

Road Test (in my LLV)
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - The sound is amazing in the truck! Thinking I would need it, I maxed the volume on both the speaker and my phone then pressed play on my music. Well, I certainly don't need max volume. I reduced the volume on both the speaker and my phone and found a very happy medium output. This speaker performs perfectly in the loud, rattling setting of a USPS LLV.. even while bouncing down rural dirt two tracks and washboard gravel roads. I am extremely pleased with this tiny speaker.
Anker Soundcore - Even with maxed volume settings, I could not get this speaker to perform anywhere near as well as the OontZ Angle 3 Plus. It had volume and was loud enough to hear over the vehicle's own noise, however the distortion/interference mentioned earlier was still present and in the truck during the road test it had what I would describe as an echoing effect on the music, specifically the singers' voices. It just wasn't clear. (I hope that makes sense.)

Battery Life/Listen While Charging
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - So far, the battery life is impressive. After receiving it, I charged it overnight (as recommended). I then had it connected to my phone for about an hour of home testing. Turned it off and I next used it at work on a Saturday.. had it powered on and connected to my phone and actively playing music for about 5.5 hours. I then used it again on Monday (much longer and busier days in the USPS, FYI).. had it on, connected and active continuously for nearly 9 hours. I have yet to see the low battery light come on. I plan to see just how many days of work I can get out of a single charge.
Anker Soundcore - I have no information for this section on this speaker since I am returning it.

Exterior/Cleaning
At first, I had the OontZ Angle 3 Plus setting on the dashboard of the LLV. This didn't last more than two stops. Despite having the four rubber "feet", the speaker still slid around causing more of a distraction than I would like. I ended up setting it on top of my personal bag, in a bin by my feet with the speaker facing up. This move really helped my piece of mind, knowing it will not go anywhere. This speaker has a soft rubber exterior. It is quite nice and feels luxurious, however... this exterior attracts all dust particles within 50 feet! USPS LLVs are *not* known for being the cleanest and even though I moved the speaker from the dust-ridden dashboard to a bin, it was still slathered with dust and dirt by the end of my route. I figured it was a fair trade, sacrificing the appearance for the gain of having decent music. But.. I got home and went to clean it. I will tell you, my expectations of this working were very low. I didn't think the dust would come off that supple rubber. But with a wet paper towel and a few slow wipes, it did. So, it can be cleaned up!

Case
I did purchase the case for this speaker ([[ASIN:B01NBDY6VP [Official] OontZ Angle 3 Plus Bluetooth Portable Speaker Carry Case, Neoprene with Aluminum Carabiner, reinforced zipper, by Cambridge SoundWorks [NOT FOR OontZ Angle 3]]]). I was mainly wanting a safe way to transport and store the speaker, but after reading the other reviews I was hoping I would be able to keep it clean in the case and still enjoy my music on my route. I received the case and used it yesterday. The case is extremely nice and I appreciate the interior mesh pocket. I have no need for it now, but I'm sure it will come in handy if I ever take this speaker on vacation and need to take the charging cables along. As for playback while in the case? Yeah, it was terribly muffled. It didn't work for me as it apparently has for others. Yet, the case itself is exactly what I was wanting for taking it to and from work. It is not as thickly padded as I would have expected, however it does protect the speaker.

Overall, for my specific purpose and intended use for a Bluetooth speaker, the Anker SoundCore simply won't cut it. However, it is still a nice speaker and will perhaps fit your needs perfectly. After all, most people don't drive LLVs and have the same high demands that go along with that. For me, the OontZ Angle 3 Plus is what I'll be bopping down the road to, mailbox to mailbox.

Aside from the microphone, this is my favorite wireless earbuds. We blow through ear buds in our house and it seems that everyone has different ones that they like and don't like. Let's see how these measure up:

WHAT ARE THESE EAR BUDS LIKE?
These ear buds come in a nice box with a little instruction booklet. There is a little bag with three sets of gel caps in it. There are also three sets of hooks. Each of them comes in small medium and large. The hooks keep the buds in the ear but are soft so they don't hurt the ear at all.

The controls are on the right ear- the top hits about where the chin is. The connecting cord is big enough to be worn in front or back. The set comes with a cord but you have to have your own USB access to plug it into whether it be on an outlet or computer.

COMFORT
One of the most comfortable and secure earbud/headsets we have used to date- love that the hooks that help hold them in are soft so they don't hurt the ear, even after worn for a while.

PERFORMANCE
VOLUME
The headset gets the best result for us with the volume on max on the headset and halfway on the tablet that we use it with.

HIGHS/LOWS/MIDS
One of the things with this headset is that the highs are really nice and strong and so are the lows. The problem seems to be that the mids are drowned out making it feel like it is a bit out of balance. We have messed with it quite a bit and it seems to be the way it is.

SOUND PROOFING
These have excellent sound insulation capabilities. That does mean, however, that you need to be careful where you are wearing them if you need to hear what is around you or not.

BATTERY ALERT
When you first turn on the headphones, it will identify itself, tell you it is pairing and then give you an idea of how much battery life you have left- low, medium, or high.

POWER BUTTON
The power button is nice. Volume/skip functions are a challenge to get used to as compared to other Bluetooth headsets. There are sequences and timing as compared to others which seem to be simpler to use.

PAIRING
Very good pairing on all of the different devices we tested this with- several phones from Moto G3, Blu phone, Samsung Tablets and our stereo (forgot brand)

CHARGE
A charge has been lasting a good six to eight hours for us. Recharging seems to take us about three hours.

THE BOTTOM LINE
These are comfortable headphones that are easy to use, stay in the ears well, and have good insulation from ambient noise in the room or surroundings. They have nice highs and lows but tend to drown out the mids. The controls are a bit more challenging to learn at first as compared to other Bluetooth head sets we have used.
