These phones are not ANC phones, they’re just wireless listening phones. I was hopeful that they would be as good as my ANC phones in terms of sound quality, and Maxell has not disappointed me. They’re not perfect but they’re better than you can reasonably expect from the asking price.

Up front, let me say that I am not a big fan of on-ear headphones, and these fall into that category. I prefer an over-the-ear phone which to me is more comfortable. These aren’t bad for on-ear phones. This comes down to preference. If you are cool with on-ear phones, these will work for you, but if you have to have over-ear phones then you should consider other options.

The pads are soft enough, though they aren’t super cushy like some others I have used.

Being Bluetooth phones I immediately connected them to my phone. The connection went off without a hitch, though the phone was slower to find these than I had hoped. Once connected, they have been stable and reconnecting is much faster.

The real test is the sound profile. On my ANC phones, Maxell worked a miracle and got the sound profile nearly perfect even when the noise canceling is turned on. With these phones, the sound profile is not precise but it’s very balanced and better than average. The bass is strong but not throbbing like most headphones made these days. I like bass, but I don’t appreciate the insistence on pumping it so heavily that it gives me a headache. The midrange is full and music sounds like it has some depth without sounding like it’s playing from the bottom of a well. The highs are bright and clear, though on specific frequency ranges there is the slightest hint of distortion if you really look for it (and since I’m reviewing these, I went looking for it).

I cranked up the music as high as I could, and there was only a hint of distortion in the highs. And I had a headache when I was done.

Build-wise, these are not too bad. I would not pack them in a gym bag or anything like that, but these should work fine for a long while as long as they’re cared for properly. There’s enough flex in them to make them durable enough to survive some rough handling, but at the end of the day they’re primarily plastic - a drop from the right height or being crushed in a book bag will break them.

These phones are under $50 as I write this. What’s really distressing is that I have phones that are north of $200 that do not sound as good as these. Maxell knows how to make a good headphone that competes well with more expensive phones - I have two very different pairs to prove it. It begs the question - why are they only making budget headphones?

I would rate these slightly lower if the asking price were above the $50 mark. But, at the asking price you’d be hard-pressed to find headphones that sound better. The headphones themselves are comfortable and easily adjustable, the range is nice, and the sound quality is great, but the controls themselves are frustrating. The pairing says that you hold until the light flashes blue then red, and I did this. But what happened to me is I held it and it flashed blue once then it would flash red repeatedly. The manual said nothing about repeated red flashing so I assumed it was in pairing mode and I was confused as to why it wouldn't appear on my phone. After a while, I realized that if I held the pairing button longer after it started flashing red then it would flash blue and red alternately and then I could pair. I still have no clue what the red flashing means. Also, the way the skip/volume is set up is weird and temperamental. You hold the button to change the volume and press once to skip or go to the previous song (depending on which volume buttons you press), but sometimes after letting go from holding the volume button the song will change anyway. I think it would be more efficient to switch to press to change volume and hold to change song to prevent accidental switches. I have yet to try a phone call but if the volume/song switch buttons weren't so annoying this would be a great product.

Before giving it to him, I had our daughter put it through the grind at work (food prep) and in town events. Let's see how this speaker performs..

WHAT IS THIS SPEAKER LIKE?
This speaker is gray in color. The housing is very rubbery in consistency. The right side of the speaker has sealed controls under a rubberized pad over top of the buttons. The speaker stays put and is heavier than expected.

ON/OFF BUTTON/PAIRING
Holding down for over a second powers up the speaker. Next to the power button is the PAIRING button. This is not for pairing the speaker to a device but it is for pairing with another speaker just like it. A coworker with my daughter has this speaker and they tested it out- works GREAT so you now get two synced speakers.

CALLS BUTTON
You can send and receive calls with this button. You can also access your voice commands on your phone with this button.

VOLUME BUTTON
This is plus or minus sound controls. You can also skip by holding down- + is forward, - is backward.

PAUSE/PLAY
You can control pausing and playing with this button.

DOCKING
USB for charging, mini USB port (to use to charge a device if need be), and auxiliary outlet for like an old MP3 player or other device that does not have Bluetooth capability.

CHARGING INDICATOR LIGHT
Red when charging and turns white when fully charged. Will indicate when the power is running low so you will know.

SOUND QUALITY
Sound quality with this is very good. My daughter has a coworker with the same speaker so they both have had a chance to experiment with their speakers. So far it has been a great speaker. The balance of the recording of course affects the speaker, but so far it has not been overly muffled, out of balance, etc. Where you put the speaker affects how it sounds too.

When put on the floor, it really does sound better than on, say top of a box, or couch, etc. A very hard surface seems to really make it sound best.

VOLUME
When using the volume controls on the speaker, the sound is better than when you use the volume controls on the device (tablet, phone, etc).

DURABILITY
This speaker was taken to a huge town chicken and biscuit dinner and was dropped and still is working perfectly.

BATTERY
Two 10 hour shifts at full volume, and this speaker kicked through it all before needing to be recharged.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For a really nice durable speaker that is dustproof, shock proof, and supposedly water proof, this is a good choice. It is solid, has decent sound , and even can be synced with another speaker if you get two of these for coverage around a room.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. This is a decent speaker, and I feel more comfortable having my husband use this on his jobs than the other really nice speaker he was beating up.

We live on 12 acres, and although we’re not planning a mini-Woodstock, we will be streaming movies outside this summer for our guests. We have a whing-ding coming up when 30 family and friends will be visiting to help us plant our first crop - they’ll be tented around the property and we’ll gather for music and movies. What appealed to me was being able to hook up to any device - and also the claim of “mind-bending” bass! Music makes the work go faster, so we’ll want our fields to rock! Hoping this wireless speaker will give us the background noise we need! Will amend this review with the results! Our family is a bunch of speaker and ear phone fanatics. Everyone has different likes and I tend to like a well balanced music. Muffled really bugs me.

I wanted to have a nice balanced speaker that no one will take so I decided to get this one for ME. It has a nice solid housing and I figured it was worth getting since my favorite speaker seems to get misplaced a lot. Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This is a very solid speaker. It is heavy duty and it has metal housing. The sides are not as fragile as others I have used which sound this good. It comes in a beautiful gift box which has cushioning and the typical Santana design to it. The speaker itself is pretty heavy so it is not something you toss in your backpack and run off with. It needs a bit more care than that.

CHARGING
This has a USB charger that will take about 4 hours to charge it up with. There is also a connection where you can get a FAST charger from the company, but you have to contact them for it. The charging cable comes with it just need a USB outlet. The directions warn to only use the original cable that comes with this to charge or there might be damage to the speaker. The voltage must be 5V with current rated at 115A.

CAN THIS RUN WHILE CHARGING?
I do not see in the instructions warnings against this, and it does work while plugged in.

PLAY TIME
This speaker runs out of juice pretty quickly. If you want it to last the entire time of 10 hours, I highly suggest you not put the volume up past 30%. Any higher and the battery time runs down pretty quickly. At 60% you are at the edge of running this down pretty quickly- as in 4 or 5 hours play time only.

PAIRING
I have had no issues pairing this with tablets or phones using Android. Just like when you turn the power on, it says PAIRING in a very loud voice so you will know when it is in pairing mode.

VOLUME
The volume button on this is tricky. If you are not thinking and just quickly press the volume once, instead of it getting slightly louder, you will skip a track. You have to press the volume down and not let up if you want the sound to go up or down depending on the button you press meaning +/-.

CARD SLOT
This speaker can also work off of a TF card (also known as a microSD card). You just have to change from bluetooth mode to card mode using the MODE button.

IS THERE AUX CAPABILITY?
I have an old MP3 player that has higher quality recordings than anything new I have. That only uses AUX and it works great with this.

PAUSE / PLAY
You can pause or play music with this using the MFB button

HOW DOES THIS PERFORM?
Let me tell you, this thing ROCKS. I mean it. This speaker is fabulous. Not only does it work great out of the box (after being fully charged) but it sounds better and better as you break it in. It fills the house with music that is great quality and does not have interference or any lag issues either.

WHAT ABOUT BASS, MIDS AND HIGHS?
I have to say that this speaker is one of the few that I have used which does a beautiful job of intense bass, balanced clear highs but the mids are not muffled at all. It is impressive and what I thought a speaker always should be.

CAN YOU USE TWO TOGETHER?
This allows you to add one other speaker to the system so you can have them in two places. I do not have another Europa speaker at the moment I can test that with.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Although this blows any other wireless speaker I have had out of the water, it does blow through power rather quickly unless the volume is pretty low. It is not only amazing out of the box (After charging) but it gets better with more use. This baby ROCKS.

MY RATING
Finding a speaker which does not overwhelm you with out of whack bass, piercing highs, or muffled middles is not always easy. This speaker seems to divide it all out very well. It is one of the nicest speakers I have used (wireless) to date. FIVE STARS!

Not only do I love this, but would definitely consider a second one along with the fast charger in the future to round out the whole system.

ANOTHER THING
This product has a notification on it that some of the proceeds from this product will go to help underprivileged children through the MILAGRO foundation (miracle) that Carlos Santana and his family started in 1998. I ordered the 'Europa by Carlos Santana 40W Portable Bluetooth Surround True Wireless Stereo with 6 to 8 Hours of Continuous Playtime, Dual Active Subwoofer for Parties, Indoor & Outdoor - Black' for review and would like to share my thoughts.

Let's get one thing straight right away: THESE ARE NOT SUNGLASSES. They are blue-light blocking at best, or just mildly tinted most likely. I took them out of the box and thought "Oh cool! These are the kinds of glasses that get dark outside and transparent when you are inside!", but nope- I wore them for a full hour outside and they didn't get any darker or exhibit any sun blocking properties AT ALL. So that's false advertising right there. They aren't for use in the sun. They don't darken anything.
As far as audio quality... they are a cool concept, but again, falls short of expectations. The open ear design means the speakers have to work harder to be audible. That means they often make those tin-sounding rattles that tiny speakers make when cranked up too high. This is definitely NOT cool for music as most of the fidelity is lost right off the bat, and adding insult to injury is that they often don't get loud enough to use outside. I'm not saying using it in a crowded subway terminal (that you can just forget about completely), I'm talking about even just going for a stroll around my suburban block with some birds chirping and the wind blowing lightly, maybe a car driving in the distance. I tried listening to a recorded lecture (since music was a lost cause), and they couldn't get loud enough to hear clearly. The microphone for calls was OK in my test, so I guess they are cool as a way to take a phone call without wearing a headset, but that only works if you're wearing these anyway as sunglasses. They aren't sunglasses, so you wouldn't be wearing them anyway, and you wouldn't be wearing them for music, and you wouldn't be wearing them to make a phone call either because they rarely get loud enough unless you are home alone... in which case you can put your phone on speaker and avoid this whole mess.
In conclusion- its a good idea but executed poorly and does NOT live up to expectations. I'm surprised there are so many good reviews on this product. I can't think of a time I would use it. I spend a lot of time at the computer for work so I wear blue light glasses often. These for that were comfortable to wear. I get tired of wearing ear buds so having this as another option to listen to music while I work is really nice. The sound quality is pretty good, in fact better than I excepted it to be and better than many headphones I have. They are a bit bulky to wear but not too bad. Overall I feel like these are worth the money and if you spend a lot of time at the computer like myself they are a good investment. The glasses are fine for uv protection. They are not sun glasses. They pair fine with my iPad and I listen to podcasts, so the sound doesn't have to be pristine for that purpose. But when I listen to music, I want better audio. I like that these are water resistant but I wouldn't press the issue on that point. They need to make these true sunglasses with blue light protection. And improve the audio.

I've heard a lot of wonderful things about the Sony noise cancelling sets like these, and let me tell you: it isn't just hype. Like my Sony studio headphones I use professionally for work, the actual fidelity of the sound it reproduces is excellent, and the microphone for calls is excellent despite being up by my ears and so far from my mouth (other bluetooth headphones I've tried were good for music only, the mic being up by my ears wasn't good enough to isolate my voice from ambient sound, but this definitely does a great job).
The app gives a ton of control beyond what I expected to really customize the experience. For example, I have mine set to auto-pause if the headphones are removed, and to turn off noise cancelling when it detects me speaking to someone, and then resume playback when the headphones are removed/replaced. These features are all customizable, as well as many more. But you need the app. And this is where the cons come in:
1) You really need the app to get the most out of this. I was thinking about pairing this with my desktop and/or TV, but without the app you have far less control, and to be honest I couldn't even get it to pair with my phone using just Bluetooth alone. There seems to be a way according to the instructions, but I couldn't figure it out without using the app installed.
2) For a set that costs this much, I'm surprised at how scuffed up it got after one fall from about 3 feet next to my car. Including pictures. This happened the day I got it. I'm not sure if there's anything that can be done about that, pavement is hard to recover from if anything is dropped, but it's something to keep in mind if you're spending this much money on a gadget. My studio headphones have been roughed around for years and held up fine.

All in all, I'd give it 5 stars if it weren't so reliant on the app to get the features going and/or more resilient to being dropped. Feels like I should deduct one for that. But as far as features and sound quality go, this is a solid 5 out of 5. These work great on airplanes and you can’t even hear the blaring announcements. And you just put your palm against the right headphone to be able to hear ambient noise. You can control the volume and skip tracks just by swiping the right headphone. Easy blue tooth connection. So, a lot of people complained about the headphones pausing for voice etc.. there's an app you can download where you can turn off auto pausing, auto turn off, and you can even turn off the noise cancelling. I personally can't handle the noise cancelling aspect, as it hurts my ears and gives me weird head pressure.. so I'm super happy I can turn that off.
